results.title: Do not pass go
results.creator_credit: Kent Chadwick, Victorian Film Corporation and Phil de Montingnie
results.brief_description: A dramatisation of the story of two young people and their confrontation with the law. Set in the streets, in the children’s courts and in the prisons, it shows that Australian welfare systems do not necessarily assist such teenagers. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Do not fold, staple, spindle, or mutilate
results.brief_description: Written by New York playwright Millard Lampell and starring Hollywood’s Ed Begley, this film tells the story of an aging union leader who, after a lifetime of service for the cause, finds that he has outlived his usefulness and esteem among the workers of his factory, that times have changed and a new strategy is needed in bargaining with the company. It is the situation of a man who must retire.

results.title: Do it yourself cartoon kit
results.brief_description: A satire on cartoons, home hobbyists, and box-top specials, in which the viewer is offered an animation kit, complete with noises, cut-out characters and stick-anything adhesive glue, all for fifty guineas and three detergent box tops. Very much in the Monty Python style - made by Keith Learner, Nancy Hanna, Bob Godfrey and Vera Linnecar.

results.title: Do It Yourself Brick Paving
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Do It Yourself Home Video Workshop. Series 1”.
This video instructs the beginner on how to achieve professional brick paving results. It introduces different paving styles, and advises the beginner on how to calculate material requirements, how to prepare a surface and eventually how to pave.

results.title: Do it his way: a case for adapted intelligence tests
results.brief_description: Children with handicaps are often placed at a distinct disadvantage by most intelligence tests. This film advocates adapting tests to fit the needs of a child’s handicap so that true abilities can be measured. Psychologist Zola Anderson modifies psychological testing procedures to fit the abilities of a six-year-old child with cerebral palsy and a four-year-old child with mild mental retardation.

results.title: Do I have to kill my child?
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Timothy Read, Janet Isaac and Donald Crombie
results.brief_description: A program which dramatises the anguish and desperation of parents who turn baby-bashers. Jackie Weaver plays Dianne, a young, middle class mother whose ability to cope with children, neighbours, the housework and upward-mobile husband and all the stresses of modern living suddenly gives way. A warm, dramatic film about a very real problem in contemporary society. Cast include: Jacki Weaver, Brendon Lunney, Willie Fennell.

results.title: Do detectives think?
results.creator_credit: Hal Roach, Hal Roach Studios, Pathé Frères and Fred Guiol
results.brief_description: An escaped convict (Young) is out to kill the judge (Finlayson) who sentenced him. Two inept detectives (Laurel & Hardy) are hired to guard the judge.

results.title: DNA: molecule of heredity
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology Program. Unit 5. Heredity and Adaptive Change”.
Dr. George Beadle, discoverer of DNA and Nobel prize winner, explains why DNA, a giant molecule of the cell chromosomes, is the basis of growth and reproduction and the mechanism for transporting hereditary specifications from one generation to the next.
